title: Snaefell Walk Route

nearby.description: Raad ny Foillan - Isle of Man Coastal Path

images.title: Nigel Homer / The Summit of Snaefell looking south
images.caption: The Summit of Snaefell looking south. The summit station and cafe be seen to the right.

images.title: John Radcliffe / Snaefell
images.caption: Snaefell (2036ft) with Clagh Ouyr (1808ft) behind (Southern peak of the North Barrule ridge) taken from the Brandywell road.

images.title: Andy Stephenson / Snaefell Summit Station
images.caption: Summit Station. One of the highest British railway stations at 2036 feet. This is the terminus of the electric railway leading from Laxey to the summit.

images.title: Richard Rimmer / Laxey Valley from Snaefell Summit
images.caption: Laxey Valley from the Summit. View from the Summit Hotel down Laxey Valley past the Snaefell mines on the left, and with the Electric Railway tracks drawing a line down the south side of the valley towards the village and harbour at the bottom of the glen.

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Western slopes of Snaefell
images.caption: The Western slopes. Looking west to the Sulby Reservoir. Slieau Freoaghane in the distance on the left.

images.title: Dr Neil Clifton / View from Snaefell Summit
images.caption: It is not always clear at the summit, but when it is, excellent views can be obtained, as in this case to the north of the Island, and in the distance, the Scottish coast.

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Western side of the Snaefell summit
images.caption: Western side of the summit. Looking westwards to Druidale and the hills of (from left to right) Sartfell, Slieau Freoaghane and Slieau Dhoo.

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Northern slopes of Snaefell
images.caption: The Northern slopes. Looking north-east to the northern plain of the Isle of Man. To the right on the coast is Ramsey. To the extreme right is the A18 passing over the saddle at Mountain Box.

description: Climb to the peak of the highest mountain on the Isle of Man on this short climb from the Bungalow station. It's about a one mile climb from the station which is on the excellent Snaefell Mountain Railway. Catch the railway from the town of Laxey then alight at Bungalow to climb the rest of the way. You can also drive to the Bungalow car park and start the walk from there. The trail has sections of gravel, slate stones, grass and rock. It's a short path but quite steep near the summit. From the 2,037 feet (620.9 m) high summit it is said you can see the six kingdoms of the Isle of Man, England, Ireland, Scotland, Wales and Heaven. A plaque points out the directions of landmarks and their distances from the summit. At Laxey you can pick up the Isle of Man Coastal Path to extend your walk.
